channels.summary: Academic OSINT educators shared readings on open-source reporting, AI survey manipulation, and military perception, plus university lab resources and career/etiquette questions.

highlights.title: The Israel-Hamas war highlights the power (and the limits) of open-source reporting
highlights.details: Reuters Institute article shared as a teaching resource on how the Israel–Gaza war showcased both the strengths and constraints of OSINT in conflict coverage.

highlights.title: AI agent that breaks online scientific surveys
highlights.details: 404 Media piece on research where an AI agent evaded survey-fraud detection 99.8% of the time, raising concerns that bots can poison social-science datasets and the broader knowledge ecosystem.

highlights.title: Utrecht Open Source Global Justice Investigations Lab
highlights.details: University of Utrecht lab focusing on open-source methods for global justice investigations, suggested as a key institutional partner/resource for academic OSINT work.

highlights.title: Queen’s Belfast programme (GLAN collaboration)
highlights.details: Programme at Queen’s University Belfast School of Law associated with the Global Legal Action Network, relevant for those interested in legal applications of OSINT and accountability work.

highlights.title: Stage Talks with Bellingcat – academia-related discussion
highlights.details: Members were directed to continue discussion of a recent Stage Talk in this channel and to the RSS feed where the audio recording will be published for use in teaching and research.

highlights.title: Emerging military sensing technologies and gravitational-field detection
highlights.details: Informal discussion noting that defense ministries, including France’s, are funding highly sensitive sensor research (e.g., using gravitational fields to detect submarines, see through obstacles, and potentially detect stealth aircraft), with surprise at current capabilities.

highlights.title: Readings on attacks on academic freedom and surveillance of science
highlights.details: Links shared to Terence Tao’s Mastodon post about his research status amid political pressure on UCLA and a recent Nature article (d41586-025-00938-y), plus an essay on Antoine Bousquet’s “The Eye of War: Military Perception from the Telescope to the Drone,” as broader context on militarization and knowledge production.

mentions: Reuters Institute for the Study of Journalism
Open Source Global Justice Investigations Lab
Queen’s University Belfast School of Law
US Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD)

channels.summary: Server staff promoted new and recent Bellingcat investigations, Stage Talks, weekly challenges, and a call for wildlife/environment OSINT projects, plus some moderation updates.

highlights.title: Monitoring federal enforcement actions in Washington, DC
highlights.details: Announcement of Bellingcat’s latest work documenting federal enforcement in Washington, DC: in under a month of federal control, 42 federal agent encounters were verified, about half involving DC police, including traffic stops turning into detentions and workers pulled off mopeds.

highlights.title: Investigation of ICE raids and use of force in Illinois
highlights.details: Bellingcat and Evident Media assessed the use of force during immigration enforcement operations in Illinois, tying OSINT verification to a recent court order.

highlights.title: Grain imports via Russia’s shadow fleet from occupied Crimea to Saudi Arabia
highlights.details: New investigation, in partnership with Lloyd’s List, identified another country importing grain directly from a sanctioned port in occupied Crimea, tracing a Russian shadow-fleet vessel delivering to Saudi Arabia.

highlights.title: Stage Talks with Bellingcat – EO, OSINT skills, munitions, disinfo, and more
highlights.details: Multiple Stage Talks were promoted or released as podcasts: fundraising and building an OSINT organisation (with Mareike Vitt), identifying explosive ordnance, getting started in OSINT for newsrooms (with Mike), the Open Source Munitions Portal, maritime investigations into suspicious ships, online disinformation (e.g., with DoubleThink Lab’s Jasper Hewitt), and Earth-observation for social good (with Space4Good’s Lisa Broekhuizen).

highlights.title: Cold-case murder investigation using OSINT
highlights.details: Peter Barth’s video investigation on how open-source research helped uncover information about decades-old murders involving mafia, gamblers, and pigeons was highlighted as an example of long-tail OSINT work.

highlights.title: Bellingcat Challenges platform
highlights.details: New sets of OSINT challenges on challenge.bellingcat.com were announced, with encouragement for community members to solve them collaboratively and share their methodologies.

highlights.title: Call for wildlife and environment OSINT investigations
highlights.details: Bellingcat invited submissions of open-source investigations focused on wildlife and environmental issues, stressing the need to meet international investigative journalism standards and undergo rigorous fact-checking.

highlights.title: Content-moderation adjustment for Epstein-related posts
highlights.details: As a harm-reduction measure, Epstein-related discussions were moved into a dedicated, mute-able forum thread so that survivors and others could avoid unwanted exposure while still allowing investigative discussion.

highlights.title: Online Monitoring Office Hour cancellation and async updates
highlights.details: A scheduled Online Monitoring Office Hour was cancelled due to staffing, with encouragement to share monitoring updates instead in dedicated topical channels.

channels.summary: Brief geolocation-focused exchanges on Chinese balloon/airship infrastructure and a Myanmar island comparison exercise.

highlights.title: Remote airship/balloon sites in China
highlights.details: A member noted interesting airship/balloon facilities in remote parts of China, including a hangar and mooring pole, inviting geospatial scrutiny of their purpose.

highlights.title: Geolocation challenge comparing islands off Myanmar
highlights.details: Shared a prior Discord post asking users to compare two islands off the coast of Myanmar, providing an opportunity to practice detailed satellite comparison and shoreline-feature analysis.

channels.summary: Channel focused on cultural-heritage crime, sharing news on museum security failures, trafficking investigations, digitized archives, and shifting US policy on cultural property protection.

highlights.title: Louvre surveillance-system password leak
highlights.details: Article describing a theft at the Louvre where a weak surveillance-system password (“louvre”) led to a crisis, underscoring persistent basic OPSEC failures in major institutions.

highlights.title: Harvard Law School Library – Digitized Nuremberg Trials collection
highlights.details: Announcement that Harvard Law School Library has put online the first complete, fully searchable, digitized English collection of official evidentiary documents and trial transcripts from all 13 Nuremberg Trials, valuable for WWII-era restitution and provenance claims.

highlights.title: Europol-backed takedown of Bulgarian cultural-goods trafficking network
highlights.details: Europol release on 35 arrests in Bulgaria following a coordinated operation that dismantled a criminal network involved in large-scale trafficking of cultural goods across Europe and beyond.

highlights.title: IFAR publications now free on Internet Archive
highlights.details: Formerly paywalled publications from the International Foundation for Art Research (IFAR) have been digitised and made freely available on the Internet Archive, opening rich pre-digital data on attribution, provenance, and art-market patterns.

highlights.title: US disbands cultural property investigations unit
highlights.details: Report that agents from Homeland Security’s Cultural Property, Art and Antiquities program have been reassigned to immigration enforcement, effectively disbanding a key US cultural-heritage investigations capability.

highlights.title: US withdrawal from ICCROM and institutional response
highlights.details: Shared ICCROM’s LinkedIn response after the Trump administration pulled the US out of the International Centre for the Study of the Preservation and Restoration of Cultural Property (ICCROM), arguing ICCROM’s commitments were contrary to US interests.

mentions: Cultural Property, Art and Antiquities program
International Centre for the Study of the Preservation and Restoration of Cultural Property

channels.summary: Mixed human-rights news and political discussion on China and Indonesia, alongside debate over conflating criticism of Israel with antisemitism and some moderation about graphic content and spam.

highlights.title: NYT report on Chinese general linked to Tiananmen Square
highlights.details: A New York Times article on a Chinese general connected to the Tiananmen Square crackdown was shared as context on elite politics and historical accountability in China.

highlights.title: Amnesty report on abuses during Indonesia’s 2025 protests
highlights.details: Tempo English piece relaying Amnesty’s finding of 5,538 arbitrary arrests and abuses during Indonesia’s 2025 protests, useful for rights-focused OSINT in the region.

highlights.title: Distinguishing anti-Zionism from antisemitism
highlights.details: Members discussed how criticism of the State of Israel is often conflated with antisemitism, citing Neturei Karta rabbis and Satmar founder Joel Teitelbaum as examples of religious Jewish anti-Zionism.

highlights.title: Content warnings and user agency over distressing OSINT material
highlights.details: A former mod explained that a controversial OSINT-focused Discord (about a horrific event) had mod approval, is spoilered with warnings, and emphasized members’ ability to control their exposure for mental health.

channels.summary: Technical aviation OSINT tips on traffic-collision events and tracking blocked flights, plus news on SpaceX launch safety and Russia–Iran airlift activity.

highlights.title: Using CPA.Skycircl.es for closest-approach (RA) analysis
highlights.details: Guide to loading a KML track in CPA.Skycircl.es, using the Closest Approaches tab, and enabling position reports to visualise the details of a Resolution Advisory in 3D space.

highlights.title: Combining AirNav Radar filed routes with ADS-B Exchange to identify blocked flights
highlights.details: Tip that AirNav Radar (subscription) exposes filed flight-plan routes even for some ‘blocked’ aircraft; overlaying the route with ADS-B Exchange data can reveal origin, destination, and routing despite blocking.

highlights.title: SpaceX launches and airspace safety concerns
highlights.details: ProPublica investigation into how SpaceX launch operations intersect with FAA oversight and airline safety, including explosion risks affecting Florida and Caribbean airspace.

highlights.title: FR24 call-out involving Venezuela’s defence minister
highlights.details: Shared Flightradar24 social post concerning a flight associated with Vladimir Padrino López, Venezuela’s minister of defense, illustrating how public flight-tracking data feeds into political OSINT.

highlights.title: Heavy airlift flights between Russia and Iran
highlights.details: Article noting heavy airlift operations between Russia and Iran, relevant to monitoring military logistics and sanctions evasion by tracking cargo fleets.

channels.summary: Only a brief remark about the propaganda value of a song used with Kinzhal missile footage and how easily the system can be spoofed; no substantive resources or analysis were shared.
Active discussion on mapping Central Asian militaries and analyzing disinformation narratives and troop movements in the South Caucasus.

highlights.title: Oxus Society viz of Tajik military units
highlights.details: Shared Oxus Society interactive visualisation mapping military units in Tajikistan, offering structured data for regional security analysis.

highlights.title: Upcoming interactive map of 620+ Uzbek military facilities
highlights.details: Announcement that an interactive dataset mapping over 620 military facilities across Uzbekistan is nearing release, promising granular basing and infrastructure insights.

highlights.title: DFRLab report on ‘biolabs’ disinformation in Armenia
highlights.details: Discussion of a DFRLab report showing how the ‘biolabs’ narrative used against Ukraine is being repurposed in Armenia, pulling in CDC, USAID, and scientific conferences as supposed actors in a conspiracy.

highlights.title: Russian troop buildup in Armenia amid tensions with Azerbaijan
highlights.details: Euromaidan Press article on intelligence reports that Moscow is accelerating its troop buildup in Armenia as tensions with Azerbaijan rise.

highlights.title: Clarifying ‘initialed’ vs ‘signed’ in peace agreements
highlights.details: Explanation, referencing a viral post, that a peace deal being ‘initialed’ only indicates agreement on text and intent to proceed, but is not the same as signing or ratification, highlighting how legal nuances are misrepresented online.

highlights.title: Regional situation updates via NK Observer
highlights.details: A NK Observer social-media thread was shared for additional situational awareness on developments in the South Caucasus region.

mentions: Oxus Society for Central Asian Affairs
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)

channels.summary: Light but substantive activity: one completed residential geolocation in Kherson region and appreciation for renewed channel use.

highlights.title: Geolocation ID 2547 – Kozats'ke & Vesele, Kherson
highlights.details: Residential imagery from Suspilne Kherson was geolocated to Kozats'ke and Vesele, Kherson oblast, with specific matches for photo 2 (46.797151, 33.354942) and photo 4 (46.797380, 33.354648) using Google Maps satellite view.

channels.summary: Meta channel used to promote Bellingcat tools, podcast episodes, annual reporting, and community achievements, including awards for open-source extremism investigations.

highlights.title: Bellingcat Online Investigation Toolkit (GitBook)
highlights.details: Celebration of the toolkit’s one-year anniversary; it is described as a one-stop shop with use cases, guidance, and honest reviews for a wide range of OSINT tools, maintained by volunteer contributors.

highlights.title: Stage Talks with Bellingcat – Arthur Brand on tracking a lost Brueghel
highlights.details: Stage Talk episode with art detective Arthur Brand about how he tracked down a lost Brueghel painting, now available on podcast platforms.

highlights.title: Stage Talks – investigations into immigration raids, far-right fashion, and suspicious ships
highlights.details: Multiple Stage Talk episodes were shared, covering US immigration raids, far-right fashion as an entry point into extremist subcultures, and investigations into sketchy maritime activity.

highlights.title: Stage Talks – Mapping Central Asia’s armed forces with Oxus Society
highlights.details: Podcast episode featuring Michael Hilliard and Bellingcat staff on how to map and interpret Central Asia’s armed forces and the logistics shaping ‘military power’.

highlights.title: Bellingcat WhatsApp updates channel
highlights.details: Announcement that Bellingcat now has a WhatsApp channel for direct news and investigation updates, aimed at users avoiding algorithmic social feeds.

highlights.title: Bellingcat Annual Report 2024
highlights.details: Release of Bellingcat’s 2024 annual report summarizing investigations, impact, and lessons for future work, available as a PDF.

highlights.title: Bellingcat challenge platform
highlights.details: The Archivist promoted the challenge.bellingcat.com site where users can tackle structured OSINT puzzles.

highlights.title: Patreon podcast episode on Bellingcat’s volunteer community
highlights.details: An exclusive Patreon episode was advertised, offering a behind-the-scenes look at how the volunteer community operates and contributes to investigations.

highlights.title: Award recognition for open-source extremist identifications
highlights.details: Congrats were shared for community members recognized in the Online Journalism Awards for work on open-source extremist identification investigations.

channels.summary: Focused on detecting AI-generated media, mapping manipulation markets, government IO job postings, misleading headlines, and platform amplification of right-wing content.

highlights.title: Locating Sora watermarks in AI-generated video
highlights.details: Observation that certain on-screen texts coincide with where Sora’s watermark typically appears, offering a practical cue for detecting Sora-generated footage.

highlights.title: Science paper – Mapping the online manipulation economy
highlights.details: Members shared Matthew Facciani’s Science article and related commentary on how conceptualizing manipulation as a market can inform trust-and-safety and content-moderation strategies.

highlights.title: Sky News – The X effect: how Twitter boosts right-wing and hateful accounts
highlights.details: Study reported by Sky News suggesting that X/Twitter’s current dynamics are amplifying British right-wing and hateful actors, relevant to extremism and platform-governance monitoring.

highlights.title: SOCOM-linked Danish linguist role likely for information ops in Greenland
highlights.details: Job posting for a Danish linguist at General Dynamics IT was interpreted as a SOCOM-related information operations role targeting Danish media and Greenland, illustrating how recruitment ads can reveal IO targeting priorities.

highlights.title: Misleading Rolling Stone headline case study
highlights.details: Shared Bluesky posts critiquing a Rolling Stone story whose headline was described as highly misleading relative to the article’s content, underscoring headline-level framing as a vector of misinformation.

highlights.title: Professor Dave as a public-facing debunker
highlights.details: Brief profile of “Professor Dave” (a YouTube science communicator known for debating conspiracy theorists and pseudoscience) as an example of counter-disinformation content, albeit primarily entertainment.

channels.summary: Environment-focused OSINT channel highlighting degraded satellite fire data, climate-impacted species ranges, infrastructure risks, deforestation mapping, and learning resources for EO-based analysis.

highlights.title: NASA FIRMS ceases updates due to funding shortfall
highlights.details: Notice that NASA’s FIRMS fire-monitoring portal is no longer being updated because of a lack of federal funding, impacting near-real-time wildfire OSINT workflows.

highlights.title: Mosquitoes detected in Iceland for the first time
highlights.details: Guardian article reporting that mosquitoes have been found in Iceland as the climate warms, an indicator of shifting disease-vector ranges.

highlights.title: US dams sinking and associated risks
highlights.details: Washington Post piece (with archive link) on how subsidence is affecting US dams and what that implies for infrastructure stability and downstream communities.

highlights.title: Retraction of key glyphosate safety paper
highlights.details: Mastodon thread highlighting that a seminal paper long used to justify glyphosate safety has been retracted over concerns about authorship and misrepresented contributions, undermining a cornerstone of regulatory arguments.

highlights.title: Nusantara Atlas – Deforestation mapping
highlights.details: Interactive site recommended for visualising deforestation in Indonesia, Malaysia, Brunei Darussalam, Papua New Guinea, and Colombia, useful for forestry and land-use OSINT.

highlights.title: Copernicus Marine Jupyter notebooks for environmental monitoring
highlights.details: Copernicus Marine Service tutorials using Jupyter notebooks were shared as elearning materials for environmental-monitoring and analysis workflows.

highlights.title: Canteen menu nudges reduce carbon footprint by 30%
highlights.details: Short video showing that simply swapping dishes in a canteen’s weekly menu led to a 30% reduction in carbon footprint, illustrating low-cost behavioural interventions.
